So everything that is done within this nation—from our great farming enterprises to our factories, even to the point of transporting our goods by sea to their ports of destination—is affected by fuels, and mainly diesel fuels.
This legislation that the House is debating tonight is something that should have been introduced into Australia many years ago. The Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grant Scheme is a program which covers not only diesel fuel but other fuels as well, such as compressed natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas, recycled waste oil, ethanol, canola oil and other prescribed fuels. These fuels are all prescribed in the act as a way of reducing costs and making our nation more efficient in what we do.
The advantages of reducing the price of fuels—because that, in fact, is what this legislation does—apply to rail as much as to road. Whilst the opposition would want to muddy the waters and make it appear that this is a difficult to administer piece of legislation and that there will be chaos in the streets, what they will find as it comes into action is that for the majority of those in the transport industry it will be quite simple. Far from being a heavy-handed process of surveillance and supervision, this is nothing more than what goes on now with checking weights and lengths of road transport units—something that is done every day in every state of Australia.
I want to commend the government for coming forward with a program that will make massive differences to costs, which will have the effect of bringing the nation closer 
 together so that the competitive force that we need to exert against those in whose markets we compete is not damaged by the incredible distances that Australian producers have to face—distances not only from farm or factory to waterside but from wharf to ultimate destination.
The legislation is simple because the grants scheme applies to vehicles with a gross mass of 20 tonnes or more and will require little record keeping of kilometres travelled, litres used and receipts. So we remove with one swift swipe all of those vehicles with a gross mass of 20 tonnes or more. Eligible fuel used in vehicles between 4.5 and 20 tonnes outside the metropolitan area will not have complicated record keeping processes either. So the narrow area where there is complexity to some degree is for those vehicles which have a mass of 4.5 to 20 tonnes which operate in and outside metropolitan areas. Extensive records will be required for those vehicles. There is no doubt about that. It is not the government's wish or the government's intention. The member for Dickson may well smile. She might have been part of the process if she had not been here. The fact of the matter is that for that narrow area there is increased complexity, and more extensive record keeping will be required.
The scheme applies not only to the movement of freight and goods—the products of our farms and factories—but also to the movement of people. The Bus and Coach Association have committed themselves tonight to an extensive program of cooperating with the greenhouse challenge that confronts Australia and the commitments that the Australian government has made. They happen to be here this night for this very important occasion. But every bus and coach operating in an urban area will also, if they are between that 4.5 and 20 tonnes in weight, have the complexity of record keeping and a disadvantage compared with fleet or motor vehicle owners.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.
—The House is debating tonight the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (Administration and Compli 
 ance) Bill 1999 . It is a bill with a long title but it is a simple bill. It really just proposes that the Australian road and rail transport industries are actually able to compete on a better level than ever before. That has been the role of the Howard government and of the coalition ministers who have understood the needs of our great nation, which is reliant—to an extent perhaps three times greater than any other nation on earth—on a road and rail based transport industry. There is no OECD country more dependent on road transport than Australia is. In fact, Australia is three times more dependent on road and rail transport than its competitors are. Therefore, built into all of the costs of moving goods grown on farms or manufactured in factories to the waterside and then from the waterside overseas is the huge factor of road and rail transport.
Australia suffers serious economic disadvantage and yet our fuel prices have been historically high. The average motorist in Sydney or Melbourne understands how high their fuel prices are. One only has to travel to the United States to understand that successive governments of Australia have seen an advantage in taxing highly the motorist—and not just the average private motorist but also the whole of the road transport industry. The argument has run that governments need a resource to put back into the road system and to build up the road system. The fact is—as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, coming from rural Australia—that there has never been a return to the road users of all the taxes they have paid.
Although we have an excellent program of increasing expenditure on roads, the government has not chosen to use all of the taxes collected from road users to massively increase the road system. We have chosen to reduce the cost of transportation to motorists and particularly to our transport industries. That will make a massive difference to the cost of everything that we do. We hear critics of this new tax system that Australia is moving into saying, `But the cost is going to be at least 10 per cent.' The fact of the matter is that this piece of legislation dramatically reduces the costs of everything in Australia. 
 Everything has got to go on a truck or go by rail. To reduce the cost of that process is going to affect everything we eat, everything we wear, everything we use. Everything that our society uses is going to be impacted upon by this legislation.
So the government has provided, by the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme, a grant of $600 million in 2000-01 and, in the financial year 2001-02, one of $690 million. That is restricted to use by 20-tonne-mass trucks outside metropolitan areas. The advantage is restricted to those trucks in the range of four to 20 tonnes which move in and out of metropolitan areas and it is restricted to those trucks which are 20 tonnes or more in mass moving in metropolitan areas. So what misses out? The lighter vehicles moving in metropolitan areas. This was a concession that the government gave to the Australian Democrats in order to see the passage of this legislation. So the advantage is there for the real economic earners of Australia, but there is a complicating factor of compliance which has been imposed by the restrictions—something that the government would have preferred not to have had but which is there.
This bill means that a person must be registered before they can become eligible to receive this grant, and so there is a registration process and a definition process of what comprises a journey—whether a journey includes metropolitan and non-metropolitan travel. The Commissioner for Taxation needs to determine what exactly a journey is. In so doing, he must consult the transport industry, the Bus Industry Confederation, the Australian Trucking Association, the National Farmers Federation and any other organisations specified in the regulations yet to be drafted. So the commissioner determines with the industry what a trip is. People are registered and then it is decided what trips are. Record keeping requirements are necessary. Minimal recordkeeping requirements are there for those trucks of 20 tonnes mass and over, and very few for those of four to 20 tonnes outside the metropolitan area; but there are substantial record keeping requirements for vehicles of four to 20 tonnes within city areas. The records must substantiate the claims, of 
 course, and they must be kept and maintained for a period of not less than five years after the claim is made, so there is a capacity to go back and identify any problem.
Why is it necessary to do this? The benefit from the reduction in fuel prices is so substantial that the temptation is there—I know it would never happen in any of the electorates of the members present here, certainly not in Deputy Speaker Causley's electorate—to play with the system and subvert funds from this diesel fuel grant. So there are strong enforcement measures in this legislation to discourage people from even being tempted to manipulate the system. If a person is caught manipulating the system, they are disqualified and pay penalties.
This fuel grant has been welcomed widely throughout Australia. When the minister, Mr Joe Hockey, announced the bill, a spokesman for the Australian Trucking Association said on 24 September that the process had been very successful—an endorsement for the process the government had adopted from the Australian Trucking Association. The trucking industry slogan says that the trucks of Australia are `Carrying the Nation'. In view of the dependency Australia has on road transport, that is not far from wrong either.
Farmers of Australia have not been slow to see the advantages of this system. The President of the New South Wales Farmers Federation, Mr John Cobb, said on 26 May 1999:
Australians are twice as dependent on road transport as comparable developed countries—distance is our most significant competitive disadvantage.
He is absolutely right. This is going to restore the balance and do something for our competitiveness. Not only will it bring local costs down; it will mean that things we export are going to be more competitively priced. Mr Cobb went on to say:
The reality is that diesel is already the fuel of the transport industry. New registrations of petrol and gas trucks are the exception, not the rule, so the opportunity for switching to diesel is limited. Blocking a cut in diesel fuel excise maintains a penalty on Australia without addressing the real problem.
The average household spends $29 a week on fuel excise—half directly at the fuel pump and the other half in higher prices. 

As I have already said, every family is penalised by the regime of taxing fuels that Australia has had. The Road Transport Forum and the Australian Trucking Association must be the very heart, I would think, of private enterprise in Australia. They have claimed a 75 per cent reduction in emissions and they ask why there is so much resistance to this change in fuel use when we are starting to take charge of emissions. Mr Andrew Higginson, the executive officer of the Road Transport Forum, said:
The report shows the trucking industry is leading the way in addressing pollution and emission issues. The introduction of Euro 2 and Euro 3 emission rated engines and the lowering of sulphur content in fuel will reduce particulate emissions by 75%.
What a great record this industry has. The National Road Transport Commission has data which shows that cheaper fuels will not have a detrimental environmental effect and will not bring about an increased use of fuel. The commission said that over 90 per cent of the freight in cities is moved by road anyway, so cheaper fuel will hardly make a difference. The loads will not be carried twice. The freight will not be shifted twice—90 per cent goes by road now and that will continue to be the case. If that percentage increases at the margin, it will make only a small difference to the total use of fuels. The executive director of the Minerals Council of Australia, Dick Wells, said:
. . . while the mining industry would benefit from the diesel fuel rebate, it still paid an effective rate of 11.8 per cent wholesale sales tax on diesel—
the mining industry does that—
an impost none of Australia's major competitors faced.
We are expecting our miners to work with lead in the saddlebags. The way we have been behaving is not realistic. Ian Donges from the NFF said that during the election campaign the Prime Minister made a commitment to the nation and that during that campaign the NFF campaigned for the total removal of fuel excise and for the application of a fair road user charge. So the reduction in diesel fuel excise contained in this package that the House will pass tonight already represents a significant compromise position for the 
 farmers—and the farmers are delighted with the result. With regard to the criticisms from the Senate, Ian Donges said:
Over the last 2 years, the pump prices of petrol and diesel have fallen dramatically.
This gives the lie to the claims of some members of the Senate and the committee that examined this issue. He said that the Senate committee's conclusions regarding the impact of diesel fuel cuts under the government's tax package are wrong and based on untested research. As I have said, Mr Donges said that over the last two years the pump prices of petrol and diesel have fallen dramatically. He went on to say:
Total national consumption of petrol products was 48,178 megalitres in 1996.
He said that consumption had decreased as fuel prices have come down. (Time expired)
debate_title: <title>DIESEL AND ALTERNATIVE FUELS GRANTS SCHEME (ADMINISTRATION AND COMPLIANCE) BILL 1999</title>

name: Ferguson, Martin, MP
text:
—I rise to speak on what I regard as being a far from simple bill. The opposition's approach to the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (Administration and Compliance) Bill 1999  is contrary to that of the member for Mitchell. The bill is in essence best described as seeking to implement the administration and compliance regime for the scheme. Not only do I question the member for Mitchell's claim that the bill is simple in nature; I also reject the member for Mitchell's claim that the bill—when it is in place as an act of this parliament—will not lead to an endeavour by some in the community to bypass the intent of the administrative arrangements relating to this diesel fuel rebate.
It is for that reason—although I have had opposition responsibility for the transport portfolio for only just over a week—that I can say, contrary to what previous speakers on the government side have said, that many in the industry regard the bill as an embarrassment and a joke when it comes to the government's approach to the matters before the House today. I suppose that is a fairly harsh statement but, in many ways, it reflects comments made to me over the last couple of days by those in the industry and comments made to me at a function—which the member for Mitchell also attended—this evening by people operating in the bus industry. They 
 said to me that the problem is that the government simply does not understand the nature of the industries that it seeks to cover with the bill, and that there is no other way to describe the bill other than as a joke and an administrative nightmare from the point of view of those people who will be expected to operate under the regime that will arise as a result of the bill.
It is hard to believe that any member of the government can come in here and speak on this legislation without feeling embarrassed by the lack of detail, by the shoddiness and the dishonesty of the process that surrounds it, and by the very obvious failure of the government, the minister for transport, and their partners in this debacle, the Democrats, to devise a workable diesel fuel rebate scheme. When the government did its deal with the Democrats back in May, the opposition's concerns—and the concerns of a number of organisations, both small and large operators in industries covered by this bill—about changes to the diesel fuel rebate scheme were brushed aside in public debate, in question time, and in debate in the House and in the Senate.
When we objected to debating legislation that contained no detail about how the scheme would work in practice, we were told by the government that the administrative and compliance arrangements needed to support the scheme would be introduced before Christmas. But anyone who thought his or her questions about this scheme would be answered `prior to Christmas', as the minister for transport kept telling us, will be sorely disappointed. Not only does the bill not answer any of those questions; it unfortunately raises further questions, which remain unanswered. It also raises further uncertainty, confusion and concern. That is why the shadow Treasurer, in speaking to the bill this evening, moved a second reading amendment that clearly places the concerns of the opposition on the table for consideration by the House and, more importantly, by those in the Australian community who will be expected to operate in an honest and efficient fashion under the terms of the bill.
Having said that, it is also fair to say that the last time these matters were debated, and questions were raised about implementation and the various administrative regimes intended by the bill, the shadow Treasurer, the member for Hotham, correctly referred to the scheme as a nightmare on highway 1. Nothing in this bill suggests that he was in any way wrong in describing this bill as a nightmare on highway 1. The most extraordinary thing about this legislation is that we still do not know how a metropolitan area is to be defined. We still do not know where the boundaries between metropolitan and non-metropolitan areas will be drawn.
I would have thought, for an operator in the industry, no matter how big or small, that that is a pretty fundamental question, a pretty fundamental gap, because the entire purpose of the scheme is to quarantine the reduction in the diesel fuel rebate to country areas. I remind the House that all vehicles over 20 tonnes are eligible for a new fuel grant, that vehicles under 4.5 tonnes are ineligible and that vehicles between 4.5 and 20 tonnes are only eligible for that part of their journey that is in a non-metropolitan zone. Simple, the member for Mitchell suggests—well, it is not simple to the operators in the industry, including some that live and operate in his electorate. I suggest that he, with other members of the government, ought to come clean and put on the table for proper debate, and for public consumption and consideration, answers to the questions we have posed during this debate.
On that matter, I also believe the government and the Democrats told us back in June that the grant would not apply in metropolitan areas surrounding capital cities—other than Darwin and Hobart; in the conurbation running from the Queensland Sunshine Coast to New South Wales; in Geelong; and in the conurbation running from Newcastle to Wollongong. At the time we asked: where do you draw the boundaries? How do you define a journey? How much record keeping will be required and how are you going to police this? These are pretty straightforward questions, I would have thought. They are questions that surely the government and their partners in crime, the Democrats, would have 
 considered when agreeing upon the proposition before the House this evening. Rather, they have placed before the House the nightmare, the mess, that we currently have to consider and debate—according to our best endeavours and in, I dare say, a constructive way.
When we asked those questions the answer was—and it is also the answer today—`all will be revealed prior to Christmas.' It is almost as if the minister for transport, as he runs around Red Hill—or is it Snob Hill in Canberra—where he lives, wants to again escape his responsibility to tell the operators in this industry how this bill will apply to them in their day-to-day operations, how it will apply to their businesses, irrespective of where they operate those businesses around Australia. Here we are, prior to Christmas, looking at the relevant legislation and all has, surprisingly, not been revealed. There is no definition, for example, of what constitutes a journey. There is no indication of where the metropolitan or conurbation boundaries will begin and end. The bill, I suggest, flicks that unenviable task to the Commissioner of Taxation. Again, the government is walking away from its responsibilities because, apparently, it was all too hard for the minister for transport—as he has clearly displayed in question time on a number of occasions—and his department to answer those fundamental questions.
So, rather than seeking to work it out, what did the minister do? Again, he got on his bike and sought to run away from his responsibilities by handballing the issue to the Commissioner of Taxation. Under this bill, following consultation with industry representatives, the commissioner will supposedly determine in writing what will or will not constitute a journey for the purposes of the scheme. Five months after this deal with the Democrats was delivered, the government still has no idea how this scheme is going to work in practice. The government still cannot tell us whether those metropolitan boundaries will operate, how they will operate, for example, and how they will be drawn.
Earlier in this process, the opposition raised the possibility of satellite tracking as being 
 the only reliable way of administering this scheme. Maybe that is what is happening here. Maybe they have a mate in the industry who wants to supply that service because, after all, they are not bad at looking after mates when it comes to handing out grants, as has clearly been displayed with respect to the federation grants. Maybe that is why there is no detail in this legislation. Maybe the minister has come to the same conclusion after five months of running around trying to devise some other mechanism. But he does not want to put that on the table. He does not want to be the National Party leader who introduces satellite spying on regional businesses.
What will the minister for transport now say if we ask him to tell us how the central element of this scheme, the notion of a journey, will be defined? He will say, `That's up to the Commissioner of Taxation. Don't ask me, I'm only the minister. I'm only the one who helped devise the scheme in consultation with the Democrats. I'm only the one who was part of a dirty little deal that conned the industry to get the Prime Minister's dirty little GST through the Senate. We didn't think about detail. We didn't think about what it would mean for operators in the industries—the mum and dad and the small and medium sized businesses—who would expect to actually try to make our mess operate. That wasn't for us to worry about. All we wanted to do was a dirty little deal with our mates the Democrats. You worry about that. You worry about the nightmare on highway 1 and all the administrative arrangements. That's your problem. That's your red tape. After all, we're just politicians. We don't worry about how it applies in industry. We'll again walk away from our responsibilities and allow industry to sort out the mess.'
I believe that, when we ask him where the metropolitan boundaries for Melbourne, for example, begin and end, he will say, `That's up to the Commissioner of Taxation. It's not my responsibility. It's not on my desk. It's nothing to do with me. The problem's solved.' Of course, it is not a problem solved for the Commissioner of Taxation and it is not a problem solved for all those rural and 
 regional businesses which deliver into the cities and metropolitan areas and which are trying to work out just how this scheme will affect them.
What I most worry about when we have these complexities is not those hundreds of thousands of decent, honest operators who will seek to do the right thing by the Australian public and by the Commissioner of Taxation but all those people, including members of the front bench on the government side, who will seek to minimise their commitments and obligations to the Australian public through tax minimisation. Some of these operators will take the view that, if it is good enough for ministers of the Crown to minimise their tax through family trusts, it is good enough for them to try to minimise their responsibilities through the complexities and the nightmare created by the Diesel and Alternative Fuel Grants Scheme and the regulations and method of application which the Commissioner of Taxation will now be expected to put in place. So much for the member for Mitchell's claims this evening that no-one will seek to avoid their responsibilities under this scheme.
For those reasons, I think it is appropriate that those businesses know now what is ahead of them. They are going to have to keep substantial new records. They want to know what those records will be. They want that worked out now and they want it on the table for discussion in this House. But they also know that they are facing another layer of administration on top of the compliance burden associated with the GST—and this government says it is friendly to small business! This bill proves yet again that this government is far from friendly to any business in this country in the transport industry, be it small, large or medium sized.
They also know that the Commissioner of Taxation is being given extensive new powers to gather information in relation to the scheme. Those powers include stopping a vehicle, detaining a vehicle, asking for information about the destination of passengers or goods, searching a vehicle and taking fuel samples. Now it is official: the commissioner and the tax office are the new `dipstick 
 police', in association with the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, `Dipstick' John Anderson. They all fit together in the mind of the minister for transport.
More importantly, we were told all this after the last election. I think the question ought to be answered about why the Australian public were not told about this before the last election. Not only were they not told about it; more importantly, they were not told the Commissioner of Taxation would be getting these new powers. They were not told that having your vehicle seized and detained and having fuel samples taken was going to be the price of this scheme.
Even leaving aside these intrusive new powers and lack of detail in the bill, the underlying problems with the scheme remain. There is still the inherent unfairness in trucks based in Goulburn, for example, getting the grant whilst those based in Gosford miss out, or trucks based in Seymour getting the grant whilst those based in Werribee do not. There is still the very real issue of the competitive balance between businesses changing overnight depending upon which side of a city they are located. There is still the issue of how—`dipstick police' or no `dipstick police'—you stop business just outside the metropolitan area making several delivery runs in and out of the city in order to qualify for the grant on each journey instead of making a one-off delivery round and only getting the grant for the first leg of that trip.
The Democrats still face the difficulty of explaining how and why they agreed to a scheme that continues to subsidise diesel fuel in the cities as long as the relevant journey starts outside a metropolitan area. All this particular bill does is reinforce two things: firstly, how the Democrats got done over in their deal with the government and, secondly, the complete failure of the minister for transport to deliver a workable and effective scheme arising out of that deal.
As I said earlier, it may not be possible to deliver a workable scheme without satellite tracking, but the government have repeatedly assured us that they could deliver such a scheme. They have rejected accusations that they pulled this scheme out of a hat in a 
 desperate attempt to get the Democrats on board with the GST. I believe this bill gives the lie to those assertions. In his second reading speech, the minister says this bill will `enable industry to develop record keeping arrangements and plan with confidence for the introduction of the grants scheme on 1 July 2000'.
The opposition would like to know—and I presume, more importantly, the transport industry would like to know—on what basis we can all go forward with such confidence. It certainly cannot be based on the contents of the bill before the House for debate this evening. The bill is clearly a flick pass; it is a piece of fluff; it is 46 pages of window-dressing being used to disguise a massive policy failure—a massive policy failure by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and a massive policy failure by the Democrats yet again.
And where are the Democrats in all this I wonder? Apparently they have washed their hands of the matter. What they say is that it is up to the government to make it work. That seems to be their line. It is not their responsibility, yet they are partners in crime. If the government cannot or will not make it work, where does that leave the Democrats? Having colluded with the government to ram through the GST last sitting, they cannot now walk away from the consequences of their actions. They have some responsibility to make sure the outcomes they promised are actually delivered. Perhaps they will accept that responsibility. Perhaps they will move some amendments in the Senate, and let the rest of us know how the Democrats define a journey and where they think the metropolitan boundaries should be drawn. Perhaps it is in the cafe latte set in Carlton or Paddington where they seem to spend a lot of their time rather than in regional Australia.
Do not hold your breath. That would be my advice to the transport industry and to regional businesses waiting for some certainty about the scheme. It seems that neither the Minister for Transport and Regional Services nor Senator Meg Lees have the faintest idea how to deliver the detail of the scheme. Having cobbled together this deal, having made 
 commitments neither can keep, they have dumped the mess in the lap of the Commissioner of Taxation and are running away from it as fast as they can.
That is the real story behind this legislation. The failure of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, `Dipstick' John Anderson, and his partner in crime the Leader of the Democrats, Meg Lees, to take responsibility to deliver on their own deal. It is a failure for which they deserve to be strongly condemned. It is for that very reason that I support the second reading amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer, the member for Hotham. It clearly poses serious questions which go to the outstanding definitions that the industry want now, not later. They are entitled to them because they will be required to operate under the scheme. But the industry also appropriately condemn the government for failing to disclose the detail of this scheme prior to the last election and in doing so failing to ensure that we have a scheme in place that does not impose on industry, on small, medium and large sized businesses, a new layer of administrative nightmares.
The member for Hotham, the shadow Treasurer, was correct. This is a nightmare on highway 1 for the industry. The government stands condemned and so do the Democrats. It is a very significant industry that deserves better than this bill—an industry that creates many jobs in metropolitan and regional Australia, an industry that is part of the lifeblood of this very country. Yet what is this government's answer to the problems that confront this industry? `Here is our mess. We got our dirty little deal with the GST through and this is the cost of it. It is not our problem to make it work. We know it is not simple. We know it is going to be an administrative nightmare. But would you please try to make it work for us because we are not capable of making the decisions to make it work? It is all too hard because in the end we were not very interested in the needs and problems of this industry.' (Time expired)
debate_title: <title>DIESEL AND ALTERNATIVE FUELS GRANTS SCHEME (ADMINISTRATION AND COMPLIANCE) BILL 1999</title>

name: St Clair, Stuart, MP
text:
—I thought the standard of shadow ministers may have risen, but it has not. I rise tonight to support a bill that will have posi 
 tive and constructive effects on the people of my electorate of New England and on an industry that is dear to my heart—the transport industry.
The  Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (Administration and Compliance) Bill 1999  amends the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Act 1999 to insert the machinery and administration provisions necessary to give administrative support to the act, which the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, the member for Gwydir—for the member for Batman and shadow minister, that is in the central west of New South Wales, not in the middle of the city—foreshadowed when he introduced the act. The minister also stated that the government would be seeking passage of this bill prior to Christmas. The reason for this was so that there was confidence for the introduction of the grants scheme on 1 July 2000.
This bill is vital to the people living in regional and rural Australia. Under this bill, which was agreed between the government and the Australian Democrats, there will be large and enduring benefits to regional Australia and to transport operators in the road, rail and marine sectors. The wide variety of Australian businesses that provide transport services to country areas will benefit. These include: interstate and city-country road transport; the transport of goods from all Australia's rural export regions and processing centres to their markets in the city and offshore; essential inputs being transferred from ports or factories in the city back to the bush; and the very bread and butter, indeed all of the goods, consumed by people living in country areas across the vast continent.
As agreed between the government and the Democrats, the grant for diesel use in prescribed vehicles and prescribed areas will be set so as to provide a cumulative reduction in the cost of diesel by 23c a litre—23c a litre reduction. Currently the diesel fuel excise is at 43c per litre for road users and 36c per litre for rail. The grant will be potentially available for all road transport vehicles above 4.5 tonnes. However, fuel used in vehicles between 4.5 tonnes and 20 tonnes gross vehicle mass will qualify only in the following 
 circumstances: if the vehicle is engaged in transporting goods or passengers within regional Australia, between a metropolitan area and a regional point and vice versa, or between metropolitan areas on an interstate journey.
Fuel used in vehicles of 20 tonnes or more gross vehicle mass will qualify if used by a business for road transport and if the business is registered for the purpose of the scheme within the Australian Taxation Office. Apart from road transport, other major benefits include: recognition that the rail industry as an off-road user of diesel, and the consequent extension to rail operators of the full rebate of excise on diesel—36c per litre; and, extension of the full rebate for diesel and like fuels to marine use and other existing qualifying uses, including agriculture, fishing, mining and forestry.
When the deal was settled between the government and the Australian Democrats, it was agreed that the government would put in place rigorous enforcement measures to police the scheme. In accordance with that, this bill provides adequate penalties and safeguards to protect funds and to prevent abuse of this scheme. It would not have been needed if the Labor Party had supported a 23c a litre reduction in the price of diesel for all trucks, whether they be city or country based.
Grants for vehicles with a gross mass of 20 tonnes will require little record keeping additional to kilometres travelled, litres used and receipts. Eligible fuel use in vehicles between 4.5 and 20 tonnes outside the metropolitan area will have these same requirements. Where there is some use of vehicles between 4.5 and 20 tonnes inside and outside the metropolitan areas, more extensive records will be required to substantiate a claim for a fuel grant.
This bill has a provision to enable advances to be made under the grants scheme in the same way as they were made under the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme. This will assist in minimising the compliance cost for claimants who also claim the diesel fuel rebate. The Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Act 1999 represents a commitment that the government made to Australia's rural and 
 regional heartland in the lead-up to the 1998 election.
This side of the House recognises Australia's dependence on transport due to the vast size of our continent. In light of this and its commitment in the last election, the government has introduced this bill and the act which this bill is amending to substantially reduce the cost of our major transport fuel. I repeat: to substantially reduce the cost of our major transport fuel. This is the type of reform that the Australian people are turning to. Such reform would in turn reduce transport costs and consumer prices, especially in regional, rural and remote areas of my electorate and the rest of the nation.
Let me also make the point that this is part of the tax package that this government went to the last election on. The transport industry, which is the blood that runs through the veins and the arteries of rural and regional Australia, carrying with it the goods essential to a healthy nation, will benefit from other benefits of this tax package, and they include: abolishing wholesale sales tax and some of the state and territory taxes; substantially reducing industry costs; providing a single reporting form which replaces several current business tax forms; reducing the number of times you report to the Australian Taxation Office; making sure all taxpayers pay their fair share of tax—no more and no less; providing quick and easy ways of dealing with the Australian Taxation Office, including through the Internet; helping you to be internationally competitive and lifting the tax burden on our exports; giving state and territory governments a secure revenue base to pay for community needs; substantially increasing government support to families and low income earners; and dramatically reducing personal income tax.
Both the transport industry and the bush benefit from this greatly. If you add in the extra $30 million a year that my colleague the member for Gwydir, who is the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, secured for upgrading bridges and roads, the extra fuel cost cuts of about $80 million a year for a new remote power generation initiative, over four years, 
 farmers, miners, truckies and many others will get back $12 billion in lower diesel costs. This is a huge saving, not just to the people in regional and rural Australia but also to the rest of this great nation. The benefits to Australia can be seen through the new diesel scheme. There will be an extra estimated $840 million annual boost to the gross domestic product. This in turn will lead to economic growth, which equals jobs—which I would have thought could only be good for the whole of Australia.
Let us turn our attention to Labor's record in reform of the transport and fuel industry. In doing so, I would like to quote from my colleague and friend the member for Mallee, another rural member who spoke in this House on the original bill in June this year and described so accurately Labor's efforts:
After campaigning against the comprehensive policy of the coalition in 1993, the Labor government was elected with no policy and went for its own form of indirect taxation: massive increases in wholesale sales tax and fuel excise. But the tragedy was that this consumption tax was not broad based but sectorally based, and the sector that was taxed so heavily out of those initiatives, in a desperate move for government revenue, was the productive sector of our economy. This is the sector that produces the jobs. It was penalised by the then government, now opposition, which, like then, is still devoid of proper policy to get our productive sector into a framework to help it to be world competitive.
The member for Mallee went on to say:
This is the big challenge for a nation like Australia that produces five times more than we use. We rely on being competitive into some of those aggressive export market opportunities, and yet we send our commodities and products into those markets with the monkey of Commonwealth taxation on their backs. Fuel has a cumulative, cascading effect through the economic sector and the productive sector where the jobs are.
My colleague is 100 per cent correct. All Labor has done in the past is try to block the veins and arteries through which our economic lifeblood is carried. It is the cholesterol of the Australian economy.
This bill will help to administer a $1,000 million a year slash to road transport costs and a $160 million a year slash to rail transport costs. This is far more than anything the Labor Party has done or attempted to do for 
 country Australia. Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, as the member for the country electorate of Page, you are well aware that regional Australia relies heavily on the transport industry. The New England Highway, which is the main transport artery through my electorate, is used extensively by this industry. We need to transport the products we grow and manufacture to the market. We need to bring out to the country, via transport arteries such as the New England Highway, those inputs that help these businesses become more competitive and therefore far more profitable.
The transport industry has been hit hard over the years through the taxes it pays to the tune of 2½ times the taxes paid by other industries. As I have stated in this House before and repeat now to remind honourable members, the diesel excise, for example, has gone from 3c a litre in 1983 to 34.7c a litre, plus a further 8.1c a litre which is collected on behalf of the states. Every rise of 1c a litre in the price of diesel adds about $115 million a year to the cost of road transport in this nation. But the opposition voted against any reduction in the price of diesel. The rate of diesel excise rose by 16c a litre in the 10 years between 1987 and 1997. Labor, the so-called party for the working people, has again let the working people down. It has let regional and rural people down but, most of all, it has tried to cripple the industry that by no mean feat has opened the regional areas of this country up so that they are able to trade world wide.
I close tonight by saying that the Howard-Anderson government is putting into place policies that are helping regional and rural Australia to grow. What a pity the Labor Party has fought these policies every step of the way. When the member for Batman spoke, he reminded me of something I have said before in the House. The Labor Party is out of touch, out of date and—thank goodness—out of government.
debate_title: <title>DIESEL AND ALTERNATIVE FUELS GRANTS SCHEME (ADMINISTRATION AND COMPLIANCE) BILL 1999</title>

name: Horne, Bob, MP
text:
—I thought this was a serious show; I did not realise it was a comedy. Like the member for New England, I also represent a regional electorate, and the people of my electorate are 
 also going to be affected negatively by the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (Administration and Compliance) Bill 1999 . I will tell you why.
The government went to the people of Australia at the last election and promised a more certain transport industry which would effectively work towards reducing costs and pollution within our country. The rejuvenated transport system was going to be the panacea for all regional ills and result in a reduction in cost for consumers. Cheaper transport was going to be the solution for all exporters. Exports were going to be cheaper. That is what the government promised us. They also promised this to their new bedfellows, the Democrats, in return for the Democrats' support of their GST. Unbelievably, the Democrats accepted this proposal. I say `unbelievably' because I happen to have here a media release from Senator Meg Lees when she was Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats and the party's environmental spokesperson. This is the person who did the deal with the Prime Minister, and this is what she said of the then Minister for Resources and Energy:
Energy and Resources Minister Warwick Parer has won the New Scientist  inaugural Lowe Point Award—and the Australian Democrats are not surprised.
The award (NS, December 14, page 50) is presented for the most technically inept statement made this year by a minister or an official. Democrats Environment Spokesperson Senator Meg Lees said Senator Parer was a worthy recipient.
. . .              . . .             . . .
In a recent interview with Pru Goward on the ABC, Australia's Minister for Resources, Warwick Parer, was asked whether we should be trying to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels. "Oh yes," he said, "and I think you're finding that we are. There's enormous growth, for example, in gas in Australia. Gas has risen quite substantially in recent years and is predicted to rise further."
A Howard government minister said that by using natural gas as a fuel you were not increasing greenhouse gas emissions. Is there need to go any further? The Australian Democrats have done the deal with the government over greenhouse gas emissions and over delivering certainty to our transport industry.
This is an ineffective piece of legislation. It does not move towards either a more certain future for the transport industry or a more environmentally friendly industry. It does not guarantee any reduced costs. All we are left with is uncertainty. The first aim of this legislation is to deliver to the transport industry a more certain future. The same government that promised our transport industry a more certain future has delivered it the most uncertain future it has faced in years. This bill is an utter joke when it comes to making the transport industry more certain. I really thought you were the friends of business. You claim you are. I often sit here in question time and listen to a variety of ministers come up in the usual charade and say, `We look after business. There'll be less paperwork. It'll be so much easier for them under the GST.'
Let us have a look. I do not know whether any of you over there have read this legislation. I can see a couple of paragraphs that are quite constructive, but then I see `Record-keeping requirements'. There is a page and a half on that. I see `Disqualification for fraud'. There are three pages on disqualification for fraud; it must be very important. I see `Civil penalties'. I am going through the legislation that has been drawn up by your side that you have just exposed as the greatest thing for the transport industry and for the people of rural and regional Australia that we have ever seen. Then I see `Recovery of scheme debts', `Information-gathering powers' and `Self-incrimination'. This is wonderful stuff, and I am sure the trucking industry is going to be very pleased to read through this at length and find out what they are going to be submitted to. Then we come to `Access to premises' where, if officers of the Australian Taxation Office feel that a trucking company has acted improperly, they can go onto the premises and can inspect the trucks. They can inspect the goods that have been carried. The goods may be concrete, they may be anything, but those officers will want to know.
Then I come to `Power to stop and search vehicles'. I find the power of officers of the Australian Taxation Office to stop and search vehicles very interesting. I go down to a paragraph that says those officers can `detain 
 the vehicle for such period as is reasonably necessary to carry out a search or inspection of the vehicle and to take fuel samples from the vehicle'. If they are going to take fuel samples from the vehicle, I wonder whether there are going to be various types of diesel fuel. I wonder whether there is going to be, say, diesel fuel in the city that is dyed with a red dye and, out in regional Australia, diesel fuel that is dyed with a blue dye. Most of these trucks are fitted with dual tanks. When the driver passes from the city region to the rural region, is he going to swap over tanks? Is he going to record that in a logbook?
You probably think I am mad for suggesting it, but you have it in the legislation that officers of the Taxation Office can take samples of the fuel. What are they going to learn from that? My understanding is that diesel fuel that is sold in Sydney is the same as diesel fuel that is sold in Broome. What is the purpose of the Australian Taxation Office having those powers? Who is that favouring? Is that favouring small business? Is that favouring the transport industry? And you have the audacity to stand up here tonight and say, `We are doing small business a favour.'
—You voted against it!
—And I will continue to vote against that sort of rubbish because that is what it is. It is your legislation, and nine-tenths of it is out there to punish small business. It is not to serve small business. You have the audacity to stand up here tonight and say, `We are the saviours of country Australia.' You have not read that legislation one bit. You have been indoctrinated by your party machinery. You do not know what is in the legislation.
I am a primary producer. I own a farm. I am a cattle producer. I have spoken to stock carriers, and I have asked, `What is in this for me? Are you going to cut your transport rates?' You have already closed the meatworks in Aberdeen where I could get my cattle slaughtered. If I now want to send them to a meatworks I send them to Dinmore in Queensland, and it costs me $80 a head. It used to cost me $16 a head to send them to Aberdeen. And you say that you are the champions of regional Australia! Let's be fair 
 dinkum. You have not even read the legislation. You have no idea what this means for regional Australia, and you come in here and speak for the bill. You are a joke, and it is a shame for regional Australia that you claim to represent it.
I will give you a few other sums. You can work out the saving for, let us say, a B-double of vegetables from Bathurst to Sydney—that is a fairly reasonable distance to carry a truckload of vegetables—or from Shepparton to Melbourne or from the Darling Downs into Brisbane. That is reasonable. How many kilometres a litre does a B-double do if it is carrying about 30 tonnes? Most householders do not buy vegetables by the tonne; they buy them by the kilogram and they might buy them by a part of a kilogram. When you extrapolate the savings in diesel per kilometre over 30 tonnes—I know one of your ministers got it wrong today, but 30 tonnes is 30,000 kilograms—you are talking about a fraction of a cent saving per kilogram. Is that going to be passed onto the consumer? Is that going to be a saving for the producer? Is that going to be a major driving force for our export industry? If you believe it is, you are deluding yourselves because it is not. All the transport industry of Australia will say is, `This saving that you are talking about is so minute that we can't pass it on, and we will save it.' But I have been distracted from my speech.
This government claims to be the most transparent in Australia's history, but the only thing that it is transparent about is not accepting responsibility. This is a government that will pass on responsibility wherever it can, and in this legislation we see a classic example of the government passing responsibility from government ministers to the Australian Taxation Office. All of the responsibilities that I mentioned, which were identified in the legislation earlier on, will no longer be responsibilities of government once this legislation goes through. Instead, they will be responsibilities of the Australian Taxation Office.
So we see exactly what the Howard-Anderson government wants to do. It does not want to be responsible and it does not want to live 
 up to the promises it made at the last election. Instead, it wants to pass the responsibility over to the policeman, and that is the Australian Taxation Office. That is what this government wants to do—make no mistake about it—because it is clearly identified there. It will be the responsibility of officers of the Australian Taxation Office. The Commissioner of Taxation will have new powers to redraw borders that decide what is metropolitan and what is not. I live in a regional area and I represent a regional area. The regional area that I represent is just outside a metropolitan area and there are a number of large truck operators located within it. They are on my side of the border and there are a number of truck operators just on the other side of the border. Who will get the benefit of this legislation and who will not? The nature of their business is essentially the same. They carry goods from virtually the same areas to the same areas; they are competitors. But this government has not had the commonsense to sit down and say, `Where do we draw the line? We are giving some people a distinct advantage over others.' This is the ridiculous part of this legislation: not all Australians under this legislation are equal—and certainly not all participants in the trucking industry are the same. It will not be the government that decides who has the right, it will be the tax office that decides. You are elevating that tax office to a very high status, way above the status of government.
I would like to conclude by saying that there is a hidden cost here, and that is something that this government has neglected. This legislation increases Australia's transport dependency on diesel technology. I know what Senator Parer thought about this legislation three years ago and I know what Meg Lees, who has supported this legislation, thought about it three years ago. I am not sure what converted her on the road, but something must have because she suddenly thought that greenhouse gas emissions were no longer important. But the major cost here is that we have a trucking industry, a transport industry, that will now be thoroughly and completely hooked on diesel technology, and that is a shame. Here was an opportunity for the 
 government to really take Australia into the next millennium with a new technology.
—Why didn't you do it when you were in government?
—I am glad that you interjected and said that, because in 1994 and 1995 we did. We brought in the ethanol fuel bounty to promote the use of a new and sustainable fuel, one that had zero effect on greenhouse emissions. But what did you do? In 1996, Senator Parer scrapped it. One of the first things that he did was to wipe the ethanol fuel bounty. I guess there are not too many people on the other side that understand—
Ms Worth interjecting—
—I know that you asked me to be quiet, but I am quite emotional about this. I saw this as an opportunity for our children and for future generations of Australians, an opportunity that this government has let slip, to introduce a whole new fuel technology. Australia has one of the foremost scientists on ethanol technology in the world, Dr Russell Reeves from Apace Research, and he is Australian. Do you know that Brazil, Sweden, Germany and other forward-looking nations use ethanol as a fuel and mix it with diesel? It just so happens that Russell Reeves and Apace Research have the world patent for emulsifying ethanol and diesel into diesohol. That reduces greenhouse emissions and makes us more sustainable through our fuel economy because diesel is mainly made from introduced crude oil—that is, imported crude oil. Australian crude is not suitable.
Over the past four years, you had the opportunity right there in your hand to make Australia more sustainable in its energy requirements for transport and less dependent on imported technology, and you failed. You will be condemned for that forever. You have said to the people of Australia, `You must use diesel and we are going to make it so that the cost factors alone drive you to use diesel.' We cannot prove that these costs are going to be passed on—we cannot prove that at all—and nothing will show that until time shows that they will not be. We will wait and see. I am quite happy to wait and see what happens in the next 12 months. But I think it was a golden opportunity that went missing.
This government has abolished the very scheme that would have helped to develop a more ecologically friendly transport industry, yet the minister would have us believe that this is exactly what the government is trying to do. So how can we believe this government—I think this is the question that most Australians are asking—when every measuring stick we use to measure its performance shows that it has not come up to scratch?
There were two main aims with this piece of legislation. The first was to promote a more certain future for the transport industry. In that, it dismally fails. The second was to reduce pollution. Again the legislation fails, as does the Howard government in that it provides only ineffective rhetoric—and ineffective rhetoric does nothing to reduce pollution. In fact, this government had the chance to reduce pollution with the ethanol bounty scheme, but that was sacrificed in its budget. This bill shows that the Howard government can do nothing but provide ineffective legislation that is covered in hypocrisy; legislation that does not achieve its aims but encourages the opposite. (Time expired)
debate_title: <title>DIESEL AND ALTERNATIVE FUELS GRANTS SCHEME (ADMINISTRATION AND COMPLIANCE) BILL 1999</title>

name: Baird, Bruce, MP
text:
—It is my pleasure to rise in support of the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (Administration and Compliance) Bill 1999 . It is a great piece of legislation. In following the member for Paterson, I have to say what a sad, tired speech he gave purporting to represent regional Australia. How much he has let them down tonight. This legislation is about providing real incentives for people in the bush, it is about providing real incentives for people in the country. And what do you do? You hark back to the past.
Mr Horne interjecting—
—We are surprised that you did not bring back Paul to remind us what it was like. You said that we have not lived up to our promises—I suppose in the way that Paul did in 1993 when he promised that the tax cuts that would come were l-a-w. `Absolutely,' he said, `you're going to all have tax cuts.' But as soon as the election was over, what happened? He took them away.
This government has stated what it would do. It said to the bush, `We're going to provide reductions in diesel fuel taxes,' and it has delivered on that. You want to start talking about the administration costs and how we are going to implement the exemptions. But you are the ones who stand responsible. You had the opportunity to say, `This is a great initiative; this is the way to help regional Australia.' But what did you do? You held up your hands and said, `No, we don't want to do it. We want to condemn regional Australians to paying 43c a litre.'
—The old Labor Party.
—That is right. The old Labor Party, the old Paul Keating style—keep them paying the high taxes. What we are doing is offering them a deal, paying 20c a litre—a real incentive for regional Australia. You would think that the member for Paterson does not understand some of the problems that are facing regional Australia.
—Where is your region again? I live in regional Australia. Where do you live?
—That is a very good example of why these incentives are there. In my electorate of Cook, we have 2.3 per cent unemployment. But when I go out to regional Australia, I recognise that a lot of Australia is hurting. This is what this bill is about.
—Fifteen per cent.
—Exactly. Having said that, you should be the first one to realise the need to provide real incentives to country Australia—instead of paying 43c, paying 20c. Instead of reducing or getting rid of red tape, you want to increase it. You did nothing in terms of this legislation. You talk about the ethanol proposals. Tell me how many proposals saw the light of day when your government was in power?
Mr Horne interjecting—
—Absolutely. How many companies took advantage of this when it was in place? This is an absolutely limited and pathetic effort. You make claims about how much it has been used in Germany. Provide the figures. If you want to find where diesel fuel is used in spades, go to Germany. I lived 
 there for 3½ years. You will find cars on the road use diesel as well as the trucks and buses. So, if you want to use Germany as an example of where ethanol fuel is up and running, there is a very small usage there indeed; most of it is in terms of diesel. Go and check your facts. If you are going to come into the House and claim all these things, you ought to get your facts right. More important is the way you failed regional Australia.
This is about providing real incentives to regional Australia. This is about a new tax system that is going to assist in a very significant way. This is about a government that lives up to its promises. Sure we made some changes as a result of the agreement with the Democrats. But you could have come along and made the difference and agreed so there would be no changes. The recommendations the Democrats have made we have supported. This is what part of the bill is in regard to today. You talk about the Australian Taxation Office determining what is there. You talk about people not reading the tax bill. You have not read it yourself. In fact what will be defined as `metropolitan' for the purpose of this scheme is going to be determined by regulation. The member for Batman made the same mistake. He said, as you did, that the boundaries will be determined by the tax commissioner. In fact, the reality is that it will be determined by regulation and it will be subject to parliamentary scrutiny. So it is clear what it is about. It is to be clearly spelled out. You go on with all this rhetoric about how the Australian tax office is going to do it. You will have the ability to scrutinise it right here in the parliament. This is what this government is about: being transparent, the ability to be scrutinised, saying things up-front. We did not hide the fact that we would bring in a GST. We told people up-front. We told them about the diesel fuel tax rebate, and people were delighted.
I challenge the member for Paterson to come to the road transport industry forum in Canberra next week. The opposition spokesman on transport should come along to hear what the industry thinks about providing real incentives to the transport industry. You 
 would if the labor Party cared about transport around Australia. You would find a great deal of support for our government DAFG Scheme. This real incentive is introduced by the government and you lot oppose it. You are not concerned about what happens to regional Australia. You are not concerned about the incentives to the trucking industry. You are not concerned about how to make our economy more efficient. I challenge you to bring your rhetoric out to a forum of the road transport industry and tell them about what great initiatives you have. I would love to see your speech: `Ladies and gentlemen, I come before you tonight on behalf of the Labor Party and have I got a great deal for you. I want to continue charging you 43c a litre for your diesel fuel. The government might want to charge you 20c a litre, but I have a better deal; I want to charge you 43c.' I am sure they will give you huge applause; you would go down extremely well with the road transport industry, I don't think.
This is about getting real in terms of industry. This government is assisting industry right across the board. This is about the election promise given in 1998. It will certainly come into operation on 1 July next year. As we know, the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Bill 1999 was brought into this House and passed. These are the prescriptions for how it will be enacted. The grant is to be used for carrying on an enterprise. It is only for those conducting a business. This is why it is being welcomed by business.
I do not think the member for Paterson can give great examples of where business is saying, `Gee, thanks very much, but we don't want it. Please give it back.' I am sure we would all be interested in those letters. Please bring them forward. Certainly the trucks are eligible if they weigh between 4.5 and 20 tonnes and are used for journeys between a point outside the metropolitan area and a point inside the metropolitan area or between different metropolitan areas. All these requirements where it is going to operate are spelt out.
The legislation indicates what sorts of records are to be kept to make a claim. It sets 
 out a formula for arriving at a claim figure. It identifies that DAFGS grants are taxable and allows the commission to determine what constitutes a claimable journey. It gives the commissioner powers to administer the scheme, including the allotment of appropriate penalties. Because of concerns about equality that the Democrats have raised, it is not available to city transport. As far as I am concerned, that is appropriate if the primary reason is to assist country and regional Australia, where there is so much need for assistance to be offered.
On the issue of substantiation, I notice that Senator Schacht said it will be terribly difficult to comply. The whole question of compliance was brought up. He criticised the requirement for truckies to keep diaries of their travel and the employment of inspectors to undertake random checks. Just like the member for Paterson, he offered no real alternatives as to how it might be done. This bill provides a real balance between the complexities of compliance which normally would go with it and trying to reduce the red tape. It is a reasonable balance. You keep a diary of where you have travelled, which is not too difficult to undertake. Having met those requirements, the rebate is available to you. The Australian National Audit Office indicated that, in terms of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme, $23.4 million has not been able to be substantiated. So the guidelines are provided to make it easier to administer the scheme.
The bill also provides the boundaries of the metropolitan areas in which subsidised fuel cannot be accessed for freight and passenger transport. It is fairly easy to identify where they are. They are the major conurbations that exist around Australia. In terms of equality, which the Democrats have indicated is a high priority for them, those areas are exempted from eligibility in the scheme.
Other members have said that there may be an asymmetry in the definition of what is an eligible journey. Concern was raised that an applicant driving a 4.5- to 20-tonne vehicle is entitled to a grant for the entire journey from a non-metropolitan to a metropolitan destination but not the other way around. I have 
 been informed that the Australian Taxation Office does not consider there is a problem here and will ensure there is symmetry.
There has also been debate about what the word `between' means. The tax office says that it simply means between. It cannot be that hard to work out how this is to be interpreted overall. Likewise, there is concern about the word `point' and, hence, what constitutes a journey. For example, a trip from Wagga to Sydney may entail several delivery destinations in Sydney as part of a continuous journey. Some members have stated that it is not clear whether `point' means the first or the final delivery point of such a journey. The precise definition of a point thus seems likely to give rise to some dispute. Much will depend on how `point' is interpreted by the Australian Taxation Office. Members from the opposition in the upper house mentioned this when speaking on the bill.
The fact is that, under the terms of this bill, the Commissioner of Taxation will decide what is and is not a journey and will assess on a case by case basis whether a company is misrepresenting the true starting and ending point of a journey. Importantly, the tax commissioner must consult all the following organisations: the Bus Industry Federation, the Australian Trucking Association, the National Farmers Federation and any other organisations specified in the regulations. Tonight, bus industry representatives are in this place meeting with members. They understand the need for this incentive. They are glad that their members in rural areas will benefit from the reduction in diesel fuel costs.
Again, there is an incentive to country operators, which is what we on this side of the House want to see. There are real incentives to rural and regional Australia and to tourism right across Australia. This is what we want. This is the type of initiative that creates employment. This is the type of initiative that creates real incentives in regional Australia.
The member for Paterson claims he represents regional Australia, but all he can talk about in terms of any initiative is an ethanol plan, which represents about 0.001 of what is actually used in world production of fuel. It 
 is such a nonsense to claim to represent regional Australia and have no idea how to provide real incentives. I tell you what, member for Paterson, if you want to talk about real incentives, try on 43c a litre compared to 20c a litre. That is real incentive. You do not need to talk about ethanol. You do not need talk about what you might have done. You had 13 years to actually bring it into operation, but the fact is that you did nothing about it—nothing at all for regional Australia—and that is why you are sitting on that side of the House. It is this side of the House that provides the real incentives.
It is also true that the bill does not prescribe the exact form of records required to claim under the DAFGS, as it does not want to add further to compliance costs—contrary, of course, to the member for Paterson's and the member for Batman's claims that this is going to add to compliance costs. However, it specifies that applicants must keep records which will enable them to substantiate a claim for fuel grants. This would include issues such as kilometres travelled, fuel used, receipts, details of journey—including when and for what purpose—distance travelled on public roads, distance travelled in metropolitan and non-metropolitan areas and route taken. This is not exactly the most difficult thing in the world to comply with—a few notes jotted out about the route and the kilometres travelled.
At this stage the compliance strategy has yet to be fully developed by the Australian Taxation Office, but will be based on two things. Firstly, it will assist claimants to understand their obligations through an information and education campaign right across Australia. They will be provided with details of that. Obviously, the road transport industry will be involved in providing their members with details. So it will not be hard to get the message out. Secondly, there will be an enforcement strategy to remove unscrupulous operators, illegitimate operators and contrived schemes. A registration system is intended to identify eligible claimants in the first instance.
In terms of the resources of the Australian Taxation Office, which has been raised 
 before, the tax office is currently assessing the deployment of inspectors and evaluating how best to employ these resources. They also providing penalties for false statements, whether made knowingly or recklessly. I am sure that all members would agree with these proposals. I also note that Senator Schacht in the upper house was questioning the use of geopositional satellites to monitor the movements of trucks. That is a sci-fi approach and will not be pursued. The Labor Party are the first to talk about privacy issues—we quite agree this would exceedingly invade individuals' privacy. Surely there is an easier way to do this. It is a straightforward exercise.
We have legislation before us tonight which shows the government's credentials on several grounds. Firstly, the promises they made before the election are delivered after the election. Secondly, they promised that they would deliver for regional and rural Australia, and they have done so. This bill also provides real incentives for truck operators, which will be passed on to rural producers; real incentives for bus operators, which will be passed on to tourism operators throughout the country; and real incentives for those who run their own private trucking operations from farms.
This is about real incentives for rural Australia. This is about creating jobs. This is about creating an environment for a more efficient economy. This is the type of legislation that the Labor Party should be supporting. The Labor Party claims to be supporting the workers of Australia; it takes this government to show how it is done. This is a can-do piece of legislation, which is being applauded right across rural and regional Australia. I am sure that the road transport operators will be screaming in the streets, demanding that the member for Paterson come and speak about how he plans to solve their problem, when right there in front of them they have the solution. It is a simple solution, and it reads, `43c a litre compared to 20c a litre.' Everyone who operates a truck throughout Australia and every rural producer will understand how it works. They know it is the coalition government that has delivered such incentives and it 
 is the Labor Party that, once again, has let them down.
debate_title: <title>DIESEL AND ALTERNATIVE FUELS GRANTS SCHEME (ADMINISTRATION AND COMPLIANCE) BILL 1999</title>

name: Andren, Peter, MP
text:
—Reaching a position on the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (Administration and Compliance) Bill 1999 , which puts in place the administrative framework for the Diesel and Alternative Fuel Grants Scheme, requires analysis of a number of factors—an analysis that has been somewhat lacking in much of this debate. There has been far more rhetoric than research in many of the speeches, as far as I could hear. These are the factors that do need analysis: the ability of the scheme to achieve its stated purpose—that is, reducing the cost of goods and services in regional Australia by reducing transport costs; the cost of the scheme and whether it justifies any benefits that might flow; the environmental impact; the impact on rail as opposed to road transport; the workability of the scheme for business and government in terms of enforcing compliance; and, the scope for the scheme to be abused.
Before dealing with each of these factors, it is important to remember how the government handled the passage of the main grants scheme bill back in June of this year, after securing its deal with the Democrats. That bill was introduced into this place late on 22 June and listed for debate early the next morning, giving members totally inadequate time to consider the proposals. The government treated the House of Representatives and the proper process of debate with contempt not only in the way it rushed the bill through but by requiring members to vote on it without knowing how the proposed scheme was to work—and both sides in this place want Australians to believe that they can deliver a people's President.
That contempt, that lack of any decent study and debate, is why I voted against the passage of that bill back in June, pending more information, more detail. Since that bill's premature passage I have had time to consider its provisions in more detail and now, with this bill, which should have accompanied the other, I can better assess the ramifications. I must note, however, that some glaring gaps still remain.
At this stage, no compliance strategy has been developed by the ATO. I can understand the tax office being a bit coy about what compliance measures it will put in place when it probably does not even know how much money it will get to administer the scheme. It is unclear from the explanatory memorandum what resources will be made available to the ATO to put in place a compliance regime. I note that the explanatory memorandum states that as the measures contained in this bill are `of a machinery and administrative nature' there are `no additional financial impacts'. It goes on to say that the financial impact of the scheme was contained in the explanatory memorandum to the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme Bill.
According to that EM, all we are told is that the scheme will cost $600 million in the first year and $690 million in the second, with a compliance cost impact described as `medium'—whatever that means. But, if a scheme such as that proposed is to work and not be open to widespread rorting like that which has plagued the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme, it will require a very active compliance regime, and the only way that can happen is if the ATO is provided with adequate resources.
I hope that, in summing up the debate, the minister will be able to explain to the House what financial commitment the government will be making to enforce the compliance measures. If we in this place had been given adequate time to assess the other bill, the government's attention could have been drawn to potential problems—problems such as that which formed the basis of my question on notice to the Deputy Prime Minister on the 27th of last month. That question is as yet unanswered, and that is not unreasonable, given that it was lodged only late last month. The problem that question refers to relates to the application of section 10(2) of the act, which sets out the types of journeys for which the grants can be claimed for vehicles above 4.5 tonnes and below 20 tonnes.
On my reading of that section, while it is clear that a grant will be available for the entire journey from a regional to a metropolitan destination, it is unclear whether 
 an identical journey in the opposite direction will be eligible for the whole journey or only for that part of the journey which falls outside the metropolitan area. There is also ambiguity in that section about what constitutes a `point'. For example, a trip from Orange in my electorate to Sydney may comprise several delivery points in Sydney as part of a continuous journey.
The question is whether the grant will be available only for the trip between Orange and the first drop-off point or whether it will be available for subsequent travel between other drop-off points. If it is available for subsequent trips, then it would seem to make the grants available for trips within the same metropolitan area—which conflicts with the stated intent of the government's agreement with the Democrats to not allow the grants within those metro areas.
The problems with this section also highlight the administrative difficulties the ATO is likely to face. It points to the type of holes in the system that will be able to be manipulated for financial gain. For example, for trucks of 4.5 to 20 tonnes, a trip from Newcastle to Wollongong, in the same metropolitan area, would not attract a grant, but a trip from Newcastle to Lithgow and then from Lithgow to Wollongong might attract a grant. I wonder if we are going to have trucks ducking in and around metropolitan areas—perhaps damaging local roads—to enable access to this scheme. And who is going to police it?
